description: Singapore's landscaping project is home to 18 incredible Supertrees.

The largest pool at its elevation sits on top of one of the most expensive resorts in the world.

itemLabel: Hawker Chan Soya Sauce Chicken Rice & Noodle
description: This Singaporean food-court stall was home to the world's cheapest Michelin-starred meal.
This $62 million dollar temple was erected to house one little dental fragment of religious history.
The busy transport hub is home to the tallest airport slide in the world.
The highest pedestrian bridge in Singapore looks like a series of undulating waves rising between two public parks.

itemLabel: The Live Turtle and Tortoise Museum
description: Terrapins of all colors and shapes are quick to bring fascination (and possibly long life) at this museum.
This house is one of the most colorful in the country, and is the last remaining example of a historic villa.
Frozen in Norway, vended in Singapore.
This rare wildlife haven in Singapore feels like you're in the tropical rainforest.
This jam-packed Singapore antique museum preserves the fading remnants of a uniquely mixed culture.
This statue once earned the distinction as one of the "Three Major Disappointments of the World."
A historical convent known for taking in bad luck babies left on its doorstep is now an upscale shopping center.
The first Catholic church in Singapore is a Neo-Gothic colossus with a rich architectural history.
One of the largest Chinese cemeteries outside of China spent years overgrown and forgotten.

The most playful of the life-sized statues that make up Singapore's "People of the River."
Watch butterflies take flight before you fly.
Across this single-file rope bridge is what has been claimed to be the edge of continental Asia.
30 years worth of pressed-tin, bakalite, and characters both loved and forgotten.

itemLabel: Kong Meng San Phor Kark See Monastery
description: The largest monastery in Singapore is home to a crematorium, a college, and one of Asia’s largest indoor Buddha statues.
From prostitutes to soldiers to business men, the dead in this graveyard are a microcosm of Singapore's history with Japan.
Singapore's oldest Hindu temple.
A disused quarry turned lake in the middle of a residential district.
Relax on your veranda and watch the light show.

itemLabel: Kwong Wai Siew Peck San Theng
description: The confluence of modernist and traditional architecture in this religious complex reflects the history of both the living and the dead being uprooted, displaced, and rehoused.
Two panes of the massive Cold War artifact are on display at the National University of Singapore.
This fountain was once heralded as the largest in the world.
The last remaining Hakka cemetery in Singapore.
Singapore's Ang Mo Kio Town Garden West is a social hotspot for songbirds and their humans.
A giant baby floats in the middle of Singapore’s nature park.

itemLabel: Soy Sauce Bottles of Sultan Mosque
description: A ring of soy sauce bottle bases decorate an important Singaporean landmark.

A quiet patch of astroturf laid out between a building that seems to be splitting in half.

Rainbow shutters decorate this former police station.

A manifestation of modernist architectural ideas, this massive, multi-purpose building was one of the first of its kind in Southeast Asia.
The oldest Muslim cemetery in Singapore, with a strong royal connection.
An artist crafted this lonely left hand as an imagined relic from Singapore's history.

A venerated grave atop an ancient royal hill, often attributed to the last king of Singapura.
A dinosaur-laden walking trail outside Singapore's Changi Airport.
A public statue crafted by Singapore's pioneering sculptor, Ng Eng Teng.
An undeciphered text is inscribed on a mysterious stone slab.
A abandoned hostel which was once home to Brunei's brightest students and present-day politicians.
